articles.headline: What Happens When Half a Million People Abandon Their City
articles.snippet: About a quarter of the residents of Maracaibo, Venezuela’s second-largest city, have moved away — and more are expected to soon follow.
articles.abstract: About a quarter of the residents of Maracaibo, Venezuela’s second-largest city, have moved away — and more are expected to soon follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was once a thriving metropolis in the heart of oil country in Venezuela.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles and Marian Carrasquero

articles.headline: In Race Against Polio, Gaza Begins Vaccination Drive
articles.snippet: Israel and Hamas agreed to pause the war to permit the vaccination of 640,000 children in Gaza, a daunting effort for health workers.
articles.abstract: Israel and Hamas agreed to pause the war to permit the vaccination of 640,000 children in Gaza, a daunting effort for health workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Health workers on Sunday began a polio vaccination drive in Gaza aimed at preventing an outbreak of the quick-spreading disease — a daunting challenge in a besieged enclave shattered by 10 months of war and dependent on commitments by Israel and Hamas to abide by pledged “humanitarian pauses.”
articles.byline: By Bilal Shbair, Erika Solomon and Hiba Yazbek

articles.headline: Dragons and Sharks on a Beach Near You: The Story of the Great Lego Spill
articles.snippet: Nearly five million Lego pieces plunged into the sea in 1997. The pieces are still showing up — on England’s coast, in Ireland, Belgium, France and possibly at the beach near you.
articles.abstract: Nearly five million Lego pieces plunged into the sea in 1997. The pieces are still showing up — on England’s coast, in Ireland, Belgium, France and possibly at the beach near you.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a miserable, drizzly day in late June, Hayley Hardstaff, a marine biologist, took a walk along Portwrinkle Beach in Cornwall, England, and discovered a dragon. It was a Lego piece — black, plastic and missing its upper jaw.

articles.headline: How a Leading Chain of Psychiatric Hospitals Traps Patients
articles.snippet: Acadia Healthcare is holding people against their will to maximize insurance payouts, a Times investigation found.
articles.abstract: Acadia Healthcare is holding people against their will to maximize insurance payouts, a Times investigation found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Acadia Healthcare is one of America’s largest chains of psychiatric hospitals. Since the pandemic exacerbated a national mental health crisis, the company’s revenue has soared. Its stock price has more than doubled.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: About 10,000 Hotel Workers Walk Off the Job on Labor Day Weekend
articles.snippet: The union representing the workers, UNITE HERE, has planned a rolling strike for several days in cities like Boston, San Francisco and Seattle after contract negotiations stalled.
articles.abstract: The union representing the workers, UNITE HERE, has planned a rolling strike for several days in cities like Boston, San Francisco and Seattle after contract negotiations stalled.
articles.lead_paragraph: About 10,000 hotel workers in cities including San Francisco, Seattle and Boston walked off the job on Sunday in an attempt to disrupt Labor Day weekend travel after their union and some of the country’s biggest hotel companies failed to come to an agreement in contract negotiations.

articles.headline: Discovery of 6 Dead Hostages in Gaza Spurs Protest and Division in Israel
articles.snippet: The Israeli military said Sunday that Hamas had killed the hostages before they were discovered by Israeli troops on Saturday.
articles.abstract: The Israeli military said Sunday that Hamas had killed the hostages before they were discovered by Israeli troops on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Sunday that six bodies found in a tunnel under the Gaza Strip belonged to hostages who had been killed by Hamas, setting off a wave of grief and anger in Israel and further cleaving the deep divisions among the public, and the country’s leaders, over the future course of the war.
articles.byline: By Adam Rasgon, Gabby Sobelman, Vivek Shankar and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Pork Chops and Politics: Tim Walz Gets Minnesota Homecoming at State Fair
articles.snippet: The vice-presidential nominee got a brief respite from the campaign trail to visit the venue that helped propel him to online stardom.
articles.abstract: The vice-presidential nominee got a brief respite from the campaign trail to visit the venue that helped propel him to online stardom.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, August was a dizzying climb to the highest echelons of politics. Since being selected as Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate, he has been the featured guest at glitzy private fund-raisers, flown to more than a dozen states and headlined a night at the Democratic convention in Chicago, with thousands in the arena hanging on his every word.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Talya Minsberg

articles.headline: France Confronts Horror of Rape and Drugging Case as 51 Men Go on Trial
articles.snippet: A man is accused of drugging his wife and then inviting dozens of men to rape her over almost a decade. The questions raised by the case have unsettled the country.
articles.abstract: A man is accused of drugging his wife and then inviting dozens of men to rape her over almost a decade. The questions raised by the case have unsettled the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, she had been losing hair and weight. She had started forgetting whole days, and sometimes appeared to be in dreamlike trances. Her children and friends worried she had Alzheimer’s.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic

articles.headline: A Funnel Cake Macchiato, Anyone? The Coffee Wars Are Heating Up.
articles.snippet: From the giant Starbucks to upstarts like Scooter’s Coffee in Nebraska, the battle is joined for who can come up with the craziest, calorie-laden, not-really-coffee drink.
articles.abstract: From the giant Starbucks to upstarts like Scooter’s Coffee in Nebraska, the battle is joined for who can come up with the craziest, calorie-laden, not-really-coffee drink.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Odessa, an oil town in West Texas probably best known for the high school football team that inspired “Friday Night Lights,” had all of 17 coffee or tea restaurants.

articles.headline: A Maine Camp for Deaf Children Carries On After an Unthinkable Loss
articles.snippet: Joshua Seal, a Deaf man killed in a mass shooting last fall, did not get to see the third season of the camp he started. But 22 Deaf or hard-of-hearing children did, including his own.
articles.abstract: Joshua Seal, a Deaf man killed in a mass shooting last fall, did not get to see the third season of the camp he started. But 22 Deaf or hard-of-hearing children did, including his own.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the three girls drew closer to their Maine summer camp one morning in August, text messages pinged between their separate cars as they tracked each other’s progress toward their destination.
articles.byline: By Jenna Russell and Chad Unger

articles.headline: ‘Moving in the Dark’: Hamas Documents Show Tunnel Battle Strategy
articles.snippet: Hamas leaders spent years developing an underground warfare plan. Records from the battlefield show the group’s preparations, including blast doors to protect against Israeli bombs and soldiers.
articles.abstract: Hamas leaders spent years developing an underground warfare plan. Records from the battlefield show the group’s preparations, including blast doors to protect against Israeli bombs and soldiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hamas’s handbook for underground combat describes, in meticulous detail, how to navigate in darkness, move stealthily beneath Gaza and fire automatic weapons in confined spaces for maximum lethality.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman and Natan Odenheimer

articles.headline: Will Automation Replace Jobs? Port Workers May Strike Over It.
articles.snippet: A contract covering longshore workers on the East and Gulf Coasts will expire at the end of September, but talks have been stalled over the use of equipment that can function without human operators.
articles.abstract: A contract covering longshore workers on the East and Gulf Coasts will expire at the end of September, but talks have been stalled over the use of equipment that can function without human operators.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a dockworkers’ union broke off contract talks with management in June, raising the likelihood of a strike at more than a dozen ports on the East and Gulf Coasts that could severely disrupt the supply chain this fall, it was not over wages, pensions or working conditions. It was about a gate through which trucks enter a small port in Mobile, Ala.
